--- In junit@y..., Paul Hodgetts <prh@z...> wrote:

> [BTW, has anyone found that these kinds of test can be a real pain,
> especially if the scenario represents behavior somewhere "in the 
middle"
> of a longer-running use case?  The set up can get complicated to 
make
> sure the system state is correct to start the test, and/or the tear 
down
> can get complex to make sure we leave the system in a good state.  
I've
> seen suggestions to use mock objects that behave as if the system 
state
> is correct to get around some of this.  Comments?]

Yes, tests that occur in the middle of a use case are tedious to 
setup and brittle during refactorings.
Sometimes they are useful for debugging a certain situation, but may 
not be worth their weight to carry forward.

With regards to testing use cases, consider writing a 
simple "structured-english" scripting language to express your tests. 
The benefit of this approach is that these tests can be understood 
and written by the business analysts and thus reduce the cost of 
development and errors when translating them to Java.

here is a simple script:

[TestPurchaseOrder.esl]

%include loadCustomers.esl
%include loadProducts.esl
%include loadEmployees.esl

create PurchaseOrder P1
   date = TODAY
   customer = [ Customer with id = 101 ]
   salesperson = [ Salesperson with name = "John Honest" ]
   addItem [ Part with partNumber = "103QAS23"
                price = $50.00
                qty = 100 ]
   addItem [ Part with partNumber = "103WQ3" 
               price = $40.00
                qty = 10 ]

assert P1
   date = TODAY
   totalCost = $5400.00
   totalWeight < 1000lb

assert P1
   hasItem Part with partNumber = "103QAS23"

> A question for the list:  How do you organize your tests, 
particularly
> if you write tests that are of both the functional scenario and 
single
> object unit test varieties?  The common approach seems to be to 
gather
> all the tests for a given class in one test class.  What about the
> scenario type of tests?  Organized by use case?  What communicates
> better, especially if we want to use the tests as documentation?
> 

Usually I organize functional tests by subsystem/useCase.

Regards,

David
